title: Lululemon Gets Another Sales Bump From Cooped-Up Shoppers
sub_head: Comparable sales jumped 19%, driven by online shopping, amid continued demand for yoga pants and other at-home gear
body:
Lululemon Athletica Inc. reported a big jump in sales and profits in the most recent quarter, as pandemic-weary shoppers snapped up its athletic apparel and other comfy gear, but it offered a less rosy prognosis for the year-end period as Covid-19 cases continue to surge.
Net revenue increased 22% to $1.1 billion for the three months to Nov. 1, compared with $916.14 million a year ago. Comparable sales—which typically include stores open at least a year and e-commerce—jumped 19%, driven by online sales.
Net income rose 12.3% to $143.6 million, compared with $126 million last year.
The retailer is emerging as one of the winners from the Covid-19 health crisis. Unlike some other mall-based chains, Lululemon was in a strong position heading into the pandemic, benefiting from the shift to healthier lifestyles and more casual dressing.
Those trends intensified during the spring lockdowns and throughout the summer and fall as most consumers remained home. In June, Lululemon bought at-home fitness company Mirror for $500 million, in an effort to capitalize on the pandemic-fueled shift to exercising at home.
